Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Integrating genomic and paleobotanical data for phylogenetic and biogeographic reconstruction in the basal lamiid family Icacinaceae
Award.AbstractNarration:
Numerous plant groups?approximately 330 families and 60 genera?have distribution patterns spanning the tropical regions of South America, Africa, and Australasia. These complex modern distribution patterns suggest a dynamic history for tropical ecosystems, involving frequent biotic exchange among major tropical regions over geologic history. Detailed evolutionary studies of widespread tropical groups can shed considerable light on the historical factors that have shaped the global distribution patterns of tropical organisms and ecosystems. However, such studies require extensive fossil evidence to reveal the timing and location of diversification events, and the fossil record of tropical plants is notoriously poor. The Icacinaceae, a pantropical family of flowering plants including approximately 140 species of woody vines and trees, are unique among tropical groups in that they have an excellent fossil record, documenting a diversity of genera across wide geographic and geologic ranges. This makes the Icacinaceae an excellent model for inferring broader historical patterns of tropical plant expansion and diversification across the tropics. This project will integrate the extensive fossil record of Icacinaceae with DNA-based studies of relationships among species in the family. The result will be a comprehensive picture of the family?s evolutionary history, offering important broader implications for tropical plant diversification and spread in response to climatic and geologic changes over the past ~65 million years. Additionally, this study will resolve the precise evolutionary placement of Icacinaceae in the flowering plant tree of life, which has been ambiguous in previous studies.

This project will integrate cutting-edge DNA sequencing techniques with traditional morphological and paleobotanical approaches, providing a diversity of training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students. The synthetic approach employed here will also serve as a methodological model for future studies aiming to combine DNA and fossil evidence for reconstructions of historical biogeography. The results of this research, which will be disseminated at meetings and in peer-reviewed publications, will be of interest to both tropical biologists and angiosperm systematists given the broader importance of Icacinaceae for understanding both tropical biogeography and patterns of morphological evolution across the flowering plant tree of life.

POR.DRECONTENT:
(Intellectual merit) The relationships among basal lamiid angiosperms (including the circumscription and placement of Icacinaceae) have represented one of the major outstanding problems in angiosperm systematics. Through this project, we generated a plastome-scale data set with an excellent sampling of asterids and especially basal lamiids, allowing us to resolve basal lamiid relationships—as well as the circumscription and placement of Icacinaceae—with strong statistical support. These results, which were published in American Journal of Botany (Stull et al. 2015), set the stage for future investigations of character evolution across the asterids—a major, economically important group of flowering plants. Our systematic investigations of Icacinaceae fossils (Allen et al. 2015; Stull et al. 2016) have also led to a much-improved understanding of this group’s fossil record, including its age, diversity, and historical distribution. This fossil information from Europe, Asia, Australia, and North and South America is currently being integrated with extensive DNA sequence and morphological data for Icacinaceae (generated through this project), for combined molecular-morphological analyses aimed at resolving relationships within this widespread tropical family, including the placements of numerous fossil representatives. This analysis will provide an excellent framework for subsequent biogeographic analyses, aimed at elucidating the historical causes of pantropical disjunctions, using Icacinaceae as a model.

(Broader impacts) Results from this project have been disseminated in three peer-reviewed publications (listed below), and the project has generated preliminary results for at least two additional manuscripts (in progress). Additionally, results from this project have been presented at educational and research conferences in the US and Canada; in total, this project has led to seven oral presentations (listed below). The results of this project have therefore been broadly disseminated to the biological community. This project has also offered excellent training and career development opportunities for G.W. Stull. Through this work, Stull has developed both lab and computational skills in next-generation sequencing (NGS), as well as new techniques for imaging and visualizing fossil material (CT-scanning). Stull’s attendance and presentations at the Botany conferences (2014–2016) have also afforded him the opportunity to interact with numerous researchers in the fields of plant systematics and paleobotany. Stull has also trained other graduate students and undergraduates in NGS sample preparation and analysis.

 

Peer-Reviewed Publications:

Stull, GW, NF Adams, SR Manchester, D Sykes, and ME Collinson. 2016. Revision of Icacinaceae from the Early Eocene London Clay flora based on X-ray micro-CT. Botany 94. dx.doi.org/10.1139/cjb-2016-0063.

Stull, GW, R Duno de Stefano, DE Soltis, and PS Soltis. 2015. Resolving basal lamiid phylogeny and the circumscription of Icacinaceae with a plastome-scale data set. American Journal of Botany 102: 1794–1813.

Allen, SE, GW Stull, SR Manchester. 2015. Fossils fruits of Iodes (Icacinaceae) from the Eocene of western North America. American Journal of Botany 102(5): 725–744.

 

Conference Presentations:

*Stull, GW, JW Byng, TM Utteridge, DE Soltis, SR Manchester, and PS Soltis. 2016. Integrating genomic, morphological, and fossil data for phylogeny reconstruction in Icacinaceae.

*Stull, GW, and M Schori. 2016. Clarifying early euasterid evolution: a synthesis of phylogeny, morphology, and the fossil record. Botany 2016, Savannah, Georgia (oral presentation).

*Soltis, PS, GW Stull, M Schori, and DE Soltis. 2016. Character evolution in the early diversification of euasterids (Gentianidae). Botany 2016, Savannah, Georgia (oral presentation).

*Manchester, SR, and GW Stull. 2016. Where are they hiding? Tracing the elusive fossil record of Lamiidae. Botany 2016, Savannah, Georgia (oral presentation).

*Stull, GW, NF Adams, SR Manchester, D Sykes, and ME Collinson. 2015. Revision of Icacinaceae from the Early Eocene London Clay flora based on X-ray micro-CT. Botany 2015, Edmonton, Alberta (oral presentation).

*Stull, GW, NF Refulio-Rodriguez, RG Olmstead, R Duno de Stefano, DE Soltis, and PE Soltis. 2014. Resolving enigmatic basal lamiid relationships with a plastome-scale data set. Botany 2014, Boise, Idaho (oral presentation).

*Stull, GW and SR Manchester. 2014. Geographic and stratigraphic pervasiveness of the Phytocreneae (Icacinaceae) in the Paleogene of western North America. Botany 2014, Boise, Idaho (oral presentation).

Modified by: Gregory W Stull
